text: [Applause]
thank you very much mr. speaker
I usually thank the Prime Minister for
advance copy of a statement but it was
handed to me just as I was leaving my
office to come down here so I can only
assume she entrusted it to the transport
secretary to deliver it to me
[Applause]
mr. speaker mr. speaker our country is
facing the biggest crisis in a
generation and yet the Prime Minister
continues to recklessly run down the
clock we were promised there would be a
deal last October it didn't happen
we were promised a meaningful vote on a
deal in December it didn't happen
we were told to prepare for a further
meaningful vote this week after the
prime minister again promised to secure
significant and legally binding changes
the backstop and that hasn't happened
now the Prime Minister comes before the
house with more excuses and more delays
in a statement the Prime Minister has
failed to answer even the most basic
questions what progress has she made on
identifying and working up the
alternative arrangements have they been
presented to the European Union
if not when will they be presented and
will she set them out before this house
and ask for its approval of them in
truth mr. speaker it appears the Prime
Minister has just one real tactic to run
down the clock hoping members of this
house are blackmailed into supporting a
deeply flawed deal this mr. speaker is
an irresponsible act she's playing for
time and playing with people's jobs our
Economic Security and the future of our
industries yesterday growth figures show
the lowest growth since 2012 our
manufacturing sector mired into
recession
the decision by Nissan last week to pull
its investment from the Sundin plant may
only be the thin end of a very long
wedge uncertainty and failing confidence
in this government government to deliver
our putting jobs at risk the Prime
Minister the Chancellor and the business
secretary will be hearing the same
warnings as I am that several major
large manufacturers household names
employing tens of thousands of people
are poised to follow in Nissan's
footsteps earlier today
we heard from the leader of the house
that the next meaningful vote may not
happen until after the EU summit on the
21st of March
just days before brexit is due to happen
if mr. speaker this is not the case can
the Prime Minister tell the House today
when the meaningful vote will be we also
learned
we also learned from the leader of the
house that any changes to the backstop
won't be written into the legally
binding withdrawal agreement can the
Prime Minister confirm that is the Prime
Minister really prepared to risk
people's livelihoods jobs and investment
in a desperate attempt to push a deeply
flawed deal through Parliament the Prime
Minister has just told members of this
house to hold their nerve tell that to
Nissan workers in Sun one worried about
their job security and the future of
their communities mr. speaker no
Minister serious about protecting jobs
in this country would allow a Prime
Minister to deliberately run down the
clock and play chicken with people's
livelihoods to stand by and do nothing
would be a complete dereliction of duty
as I received mr. speaker the Prime
Minister's letter yesterday in response
to Labour's brexit plan it became
clearer to me
the Prime Minister is merely engaged in
the pretence of working across
Parliament to find solutions
she is not indicated she will move one
iota away from her rejected deal or any
of her red lines on the backstop the
Prime Minister's pointed out labour also
has concerns but let's make no mistake
about it that has never been a major
issue with the Prime Minister's deal
indeed in order to stop the UK falling
into the backstop we need a permanent
customs union
a permanent customs union and a strong
single market deal that is the key mr.
speaker to maintaining an open border on
the island of Ireland that is key to
protecting jobs industry and living
standards in this country that is why
it's backed by businesses who employ and
trade unions who represent millions of
workers in this country and to correct
the Prime Minister's claim in a
statement we want to negotiate a new UK
EU customs union as I set out in my
letter the Prime Minister says there is
no need to negotiate a customs union as
her deal provides for the benefit of
being in one I'm afraid mr. speaker that
is simply not the case the deal the
Prime Minister negotiated means there
will be barriers to trade in goods and
there will not be frictionless trade
putting manufacturers across the country
at a huge disadvantage this is made
quite clear in the political declaration
especially when it says and I quote the
parties will form separate markets and
distinct legal orders and concedes that
my quote can lead to a spectrum of
different outcomes for administrative
processes as well as checks and controls
nothing is secured the Prime Minister is
also trying to win support for a deal by
promising to protect workers rights
after breakfast ooh well mr. speaker
just look at the record of the party
opposite they attack trade union rights
through the trade union Act
they kept this house up all night
opposing the minimum wage in 1997 they
are the party that introduced employment
tribunal fees and introduced the public
sector pay cap for many of them mr.
speaker ripping up rights is what brexit
is all about take the Secretary of State
for international trade he once wrote
it's too difficult to hire and fire too
expensive to take on new employees and
went on to say it is intellectually
unsustainable to believe that workplace
rights should remain untouchable that
was the Secretary of State for trade no
wonder trade union leaders like Tim
Roach of the GMB France the Grady the
Secretary of the TU C have rejected the
Prime Minister's inadequate pledges and
it's vital to mr. speaker that we keep
pace with the best consumer safeguards
and environmental protections as if the
warnings of the destruction of our
diverse our biodiverse natural life are
not serious enough we had to be very
have to be very serious about all
environmental protections and indeed
make them much stronger mr. speaker
there is a sensible way forward but the
Prime Minister is refusing to listen
Labor's alternative has been widely
welcomed as a way of breaking the
impasse from well from business leaders
European leaders and even from some
Conservative MPs but the Prime Minister
refuses to listen Mr Speaker I urge all
members across this house to think about
the damage the Prime Minister's strategy
is doing the threat to industry and
skilled jobs and communities all across
this country now is not the time to
stand idly by now is the time
to stand up and do the right thing to
rule out No Deal
and back Labour's alternative plan thank
you Thank You mr. speaker first of all
the right honourable gentleman mentioned
the announcement that's been made by
Nissan I think for this house it's
important to recognize that Nissan have
confirmed that none of the current 7,000
jobs at the plant will be lost they
remain committed to the UK and indeed
indeed they will be making more cab more
capital we invested in Sunderland and
was originally planned in 2016 the right
honourable gentleman asked me about
progress on alternative arrangements and
asked whether these were going to be put
before the European Commission can I
remind him what I said in my statement
which was yesterday my right honourable
friend the Secretary of State for
exiting the European Union met with
Michel Barnier to discuss the ideas put
forward by the alternative arrangements
working group comprised of a number of
my honourable and right honourable
friends I think that answers his a
question he talked about he talked about
Labour's proposal I reference the issue
of the customs union in my statement but
of course he also talks about being a
member of the single market being a
member the single market means accepting
free movement one of the things one of
the things that people voted for when
they voted to leave the European Union
was to bring an end to free movement and
that is what this government will
deliver he asked about dates for the
process for votes that were going to are
going to take place in this house I set
those out in my statement as well he
referenced businesses quite a lot
because businesses but the deal and
they did he talks he talked about
uncertainty he talked about uncertainty
of course the best way to end
uncertainty is to vote for a deal and he
talked about he talked about he talked
about running down the clock no I was I
wanted to have this sorted before
Christmas I bought
[Applause]
Oh mr. Mathison I have nurtured for a
long time and ambition to see you become
a statesman I think you are threatening
that prospect by these noises
gesticulations Homme Buddha like the
Prime Minister Thank You mr. speaker the
field was negotiated before Christmas so
I wasn't in it's not me who's trying to
run down the clock and it's no good
labor members who voted against the deal
so pointing their fingers across the
house every time somebody votes against
a deal the risk of No Deal increases the
right honourable gentleman talked about
acting in the national interest yes we
should be acting in the national
interest and the actual interest is in
getting a deal agreed with this
Parliament through this Parliament that
is why we are working with the European
Union in everything that we're doing and
the right honourable gentleman made
several references in his in his
response to the issues of businesses and
the issue of jobs and of protecting jobs
the deal we negotiated with European
Union we're going back to deal with this
issue of the backstop for the deal we've
negotiated the political declaration
that sets out the future is a deal that
protects jobs and the one thing that we
know would threaten jobs in this country
would be a Labour government
